name: Gender transcending larrikins
description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

key_work.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen for DOS
key_work.creator_credit: Interactive Binary Illusions, John Passfield and WarnerActive
key_work.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
key_work.brief_description: Science supervillains are popular across genres, and evil Dr Ironstein from Flight of the Amazon Queen is just such a nefarious mastermind. He has a secret underground bunker with a high-tech lab where he has developed the dino-ray to create an army of dinosaur women with which he plans to rule the world.

constellations_primary.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_primary.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

start.title: Number 96
start.brief_description: Number 96 was a popular soap set in a Sydney apartment block. Cash Harmon Television produced the series for Network Ten, which requested a Coronation Street-type serial, and specifically one that explored adult subjects.

constellations_other.name: 1970s TV
constellations_other.description: The 1970s was a thrilling time in Australian television as productions expanded in scale, scope, and ambition.

constellations_other.name: Page to screen
constellations_other.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

end.title: Paris Is Burning
end.creator_credit: Barry Swimar, Jennie Livingston and Richard Dooley
end.brief_description: Where does voguing come from, and what, exactly, is throwing shade? This landmark documentary provides a vibrant snapshot of the 1980s through the eyes of New York City’s African American and Latinx Harlem drag-ball scene. Made over seven years, PARIS IS BURNING offers an intimate portrait of rival fashion “houses,” from fierce contests for trophies to house mothers offering sustenance in a world rampant with homophobia, transphobia, racism, AIDS, and poverty. Featuring legendary voguers, drag queens, and trans women — including Willi Ninja, Pepper LaBeija, Dorian Corey, and Venus Xtravaganza.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

links.description: While drag is sometimes associated with only gay cisgender men, its history is much more complex and diverse. Drag performance has a distinct cultural history that is fundamentally interwoven with ballroom culture, and the trans community, as explored by the groundbreaking 1990 documentary, Paris is Burning.

start.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen for DOS

end.title: The Dame Edna Experience
end.brief_description: Barry Humphies’ iconic character, Dame Edna Everage, brought drag to the comedy main stage in Australia. Humphries first performed the satirical character on screen in 1956, where an interview with ‘Mrs Everage’ screened on Channel HSV-7’s first day of programming, and continued on to star in several TV Shows, including The Dame Edna Experience.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

links.description: In Flight of the Amazon Queen, protagonist Joe King dons a pair of fake breasts and borrows a dress from Lola the Showgirl in order to escape the gangsters holding him captive. Cross-dressing has been a significant feature of Australian comedy for over 60 years. Barry Humphries’ comedy persona, Dame Edna Everage was an early example, first performing as the Dame in 1956.

start.title: The Dame Edna Experience
start.brief_description: Barry Humphies’ iconic character, Dame Edna Everage, brought drag to the comedy main stage in Australia. Humphries first performed the satirical character on screen in 1956, where an interview with ‘Mrs Everage’ screened on Channel HSV-7’s first day of programming, and continued on to star in several TV Shows, including The Dame Edna Experience.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

end.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
end.creator_credit: Stephan Elliott, Al Clark, Michael Hamlyn, Latent Image and Specific Films
end.brief_description: When drag queen Anthony (Hugo Weaving) takes his act on the road with fellow cross-dresser Adam (Guy Pearce) and transsexual Bernadette (Terence Stamp). In their colorful bus, Priscilla, the three performers travel across the Australian desert performing for enthusiastic crowds and homophobic locals.

constellations_primary.name: Joy of drag
constellations_primary.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

links.description: Barry Humphries is a straight man cross-dressing as a woman when he plays Dame Edna Everage - but Australia has a long history of queer drag, too. In 1994, drag road-trip film The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, became a surprise international hit. The film’s irreverent, Aussie sense of humour paved the way for a story about queer life to enter the mainstream in a conservative time.

links.description:
Trans cabaret performer and actress, Carol Byron, was one of the biggest inspirations for The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert. She performed under the stage name ‘Carlotta’ with iconic Sydney drag cabaret showcase, Les Girls, starting in 1963. In 1973, Byron became the first trans actor to play a trans role in the world, when she took the role of showgirl Robyn Ross in Australian soapie,

Number 96.

start.title: Paris Is Burning
start.creator_credit: Barry Swimar, Jennie Livingston and Richard Dooley
start.brief_description: Where does voguing come from, and what, exactly, is throwing shade? This landmark documentary provides a vibrant snapshot of the 1980s through the eyes of New York City’s African American and Latinx Harlem drag-ball scene. Made over seven years, PARIS IS BURNING offers an intimate portrait of rival fashion “houses,” from fierce contests for trophies to house mothers offering sustenance in a world rampant with homophobia, transphobia, racism, AIDS, and poverty. Featuring legendary voguers, drag queens, and trans women — including Willi Ninja, Pepper LaBeija, Dorian Corey, and Venus Xtravaganza.

end.title: Black Divaz
end.brief_description: This documentary explores the inaugural Miss First Nations competition and goes beyond the glitz, glue guns and glamour of black drag in an intimate portrait of what it means to be an Indigenous drag queen today.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins
constellations_other.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

links.description: Paris is Burning also shows that drag has its ties in Black and Latinx culture. Drag has its roots in Black and Latinx culture. Adrian Russell Willis’ documentary Black Divas, which follows six Aboriginal drag queens who competed in the first First Nations beauty pageant, explores the fact that drag in this country has a Bla(c)K history, too.
